Award.AwardTitle: Gamma-Ray Bursts: From Progenitors to Probes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to carry out a systematic study, from radio to gamma-ray wavelengths, of the
progenitors and explosion properties of short- and long-duration gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) -- the most extreme form of astronomical transient phenomena -- and to exploit their intense brightness to study the chemical enrichment of galaxies at unprecedented redshifts. The project will provide a comprehensive set of GRB and host galaxy observations to both determine the nature of GRB progenitors and to probe the high redshift universe. The results will be used to confront theoretical GRB progenitor models, and to uncover the evolution of galaxies and the intergalactic medium at high redshift.

Broader impacts of the work include training of undergraduate and graduate students, and postdocs. The project will introduce the dynamic universe to middle- and high school students across the country, through a new program with the Harvard-Smithsonian MicroObservatory, a network of automated on-line telescopes. The program will enable students to design and execute their own GRB and supernova observations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The key goals of this NSF program ("Gamma-Ray Bursts: From Progenitors to Probes") were: (i) to study the composition of the GRB ejecta using early radio observations designed to capture the reverse shock; (ii) to study the energy scale and properties of GRBs using multi-wavelength afterglow observations; (iii) to determinethe basic properties of the short-duration GRBs (energy, density, geometry), as well as the nature of their host galaxies and progenitors; and (iv) to use GRBs as probes of distant galaxies and of galaxy evolution.  The key observational approaches were rapid observations of GRBs from radio to gamma-rays, combined with long-term follow-up observations of their host galaxies in the optical and infrared.

The key outcomes of the program included: (i) the demonstration that the progenitors of short GRBs are compact-object binaries (NS-NS and/or NS-BH) undergoing mergers, indicating that short GRBs are a key electromagnetic counterpart of gravitational wave sources; (ii) the demonstration that the ejecta in long GRBs is baryonic in nature and leads to strong reverse shock emission; (iii) the demonstration that the host galaxies of long GRBs span a wide range of properties and can be used to study basic galaxy properties at high redshift; and (iv) the demonstrationthat long GRBs at z>6 have the same progenitors as long GRBs at lower redshifts.  The results of the project were published in 29 refereed papers, led to one PhD thesis, and to numerous presentations at domestic and international conferences.

Several undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows were involved in the research funded by this program. These participants learned how to utilize data spanning radio to gamma-rays.  They also explored a wide range of scientific topics,including the explosion properties of GRBs, the properties of compact object binaries, and the properties of high redshift galaxies.
